title: 'Most FAVOURED nation' EU Brexit negotiator hints UK will get SPECIAL STATUS in divorce
text:
'Most FAVOURED nation' EU Brexit negotiator hints UK will get SPECIAL STATUS in divorce 'Most FAVOURED nation' EU Brexit negotiator hints UK will get SPECIAL STATUS in divorce THE European Union’s top Brexit negotiator may have just let slip that the Brussels bloc is about to cave and offer Britain a cushy deal at the same time as turning the UK into an annexed nation such as Ukraine. PUBLISHED: 21:12, Wed, Mar 29, 2017 | UPDATED: 21:47, Wed, Mar 29, 2017 GETTY Guy Verhofstadt said Article 217 could be the best solution, meaning Britain may get great deal 
Guy Verhofstadt, Leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group, came out and said an association agreement between Britain and the EU based on Article 217 of the Lisbon Treaty “should be the best solution”. 
But such an arrangement, akin the the one currently being ratified with Ukraine, could offer Britain “most favoured nation treatment” and a “privileged relationship” with the Eurozone. 
This means Britain could be granted the most favourable trading terms available under EU rules. Related articles Gina Miller slapped down for being 'too gloomy' over post-Brexit trade 
Moreover, the Article 217 association agreement “often replaces a cooperation agreement thereby intensifying the relations between the partners”, according to the European External Action Service. 
While Mr Verhofstadt said the EU would never accept a trade-off between security and commerce, Brussels may have no choice. 
Britain is the largest contributor to Europol, sending 35,000 messages last year, and the UK leads the way in Europe in clamping down on cross-border child sexual exploitation and money laundering. Related videos Gina Miller slapped down for being 'too gloomy' over post-Brexit trade 
Around 40 per cent of all Europol cases also have some kind of UK involvement. 
Veteran Tory MP Tim Loughton told Express.co.uk: “Britain contributes more than any other nation to Europol so can we stop all this nonsense about Britain cutting itself off from information sharing. GETTY A string of European big wigs today said they felt 'sad' at Brexit vote 
“We can have a bespoke relationship with Europol.” 
Article 217, already enforced between the EU and Albania, Algeria, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Chile, Egypt and several other nations, states: “The Union may conclude with one or more third countries or international organisations agreements establishing an association involving reciprocal rights and obligations, common action and special procedure.” 
It comes as other European figures, such as France's Francois Hollande, have said Britain will find Brexit "painful". Brexit day LIVE: images from around the country as Britain invokes Article 50 Wed, March 29, 2017 The country reacts as Theresa May officially invokes Article 50, and begins the process of Britain leaving the European Union PA 1 of 22 Prime Minister Theresa May announces in the House of Commons that she has triggered Article 50, starting a two-year countdown to the UK leaving the EU 
Earlier Jean-Claude Juncker and Donald Tusk both expressed their sorrow at Britain's EU exit. 
Negotiations are set to get underway immediately and Mr Verhofstadt, from Belgium, said the parliament would accept a three-year transition period. Related articles
